Continuous functions with universally divergent
Fourier series on small subsets of the circle
Jürgen Müller
November 21, 2018
Abstract
It is shown that quasi all continuous functions on the unit circle have
the property that, for many small subsets E of the circle, the partial
sums of their Fourier series considered as functions restricted to E exhibit
certain universality properties.

AMS-classification: 42A63,42A65,54E52
Keywords: universal divergence, Fourier series, Baire's theorem

1

Introduction and results

Since Du Bois Reymond's work it is known that Fourier series of continuous
functions may diverge in some points of the unit circle T = R/2πZ. Of course, in
view of Carleson's theorem, this can only happen on a set of vanishing Lebesgue
measure.
Actually, nowadays divergence is seen as generic phenomenon:
Let (X, d) be a complete metric space. A property is said to be satisfied by quasi
all x ∈ X if it is satisfied on a residual set in X (that is, on a set containing a
dense Gδ set).
We consider, for compact sets E ⊂ T,
C(E) := {f : E → C, f continuous},

||f ||E := max |f (t)|
t∈E

as well as || * || := || * ||T .
Then quasi all f ∈ (C(T), || * ||) enjoy the property that their Fourier series
diverge in quasi all points of T (see, for example, Theorem 1.1 in Kahane's
expository paper [Kah] which is a rich source of related results).
The question arises to what extend divergence of (sn f )n , where sn f denotes the
n-th partial sum of the Fourier series of f , may take place for such functions. Our
first result shows that for countable E ⊂ T the divergence may be "maximal"
on E:

1

 Theorem 1 For each countable set E ⊂ T quasi all f ∈ C(T) enjoy the property
that for every function h : E → C there is a subsequence of (sn f ) converging
pointwise to h on E.
Proofs are postponed to Section 2.
The question arises which uncountable sets E show a "pointwise universality"
property as in Theorem 1 for some f ∈ C(T). Of course, possible limit functions
are resticted to the first Baire class. It is well-known that trigonometric series
(and even Taylor series of functions holomorphic in the unit disk) exist with
the property that every function of the first Baire class is a pointwise limit
of a subsequence of the series on T (see, e.g. [Kah], Corollary 2.3, and [Nes]).
However, in the case of Fourier series of continuous functions Carleson's theorem
shows that E must have vanishing Lebesgue measure and, moreover, it turns
out that universal divergence sets also have to be topologicaly small in the sense
of being of first category. This is in some contrast to the well-known fact that
every set E of vanishing measure is a set of (unbounded) divergence for some
f ∈ C(T) (see, e. g. [Kat], Theorem II 3.4).
In fact, from Carleson's theorem we can easily obtain that f has special attraction as limit point not only almost everywhere but also quasi everywhere:
If f ∈ C(T) and (nj ) are so that (snj f )j converges pointwise to some function
h on a set A ⊂ T, then h differs from f at most on a set of first category.
This follows immediately from
Proposition 1 If f ∈ C(T) and (snj f )j is a subsequence of (sn f )n then there
is a dense Gδ -subset E of T so that for all t ∈ E a subsequence of (snj f (t))
tends to f (t).
We may also ask about uniform convergence of subsequences of (sn f ) on subsets
E of the unit circle. If {sn f|E : n ∈ N} is dense in C(E) we say that (sn f ) is
uniformly universal on E. Denoting by K(T) the (complete) metric space of all
compact, nonempty subsets of T equipped with the Hausdorff metric, we have
Theorem 2 Quasi all continuous functions on T enjoy that property that (sn f )
is uniformly universal on quasi all sets E ∈ K(T).
It can be shown (see [Kö]) that quasi all elements of K(T) are perfect sets. In
particular, there are perfect – and thus uncountable – sets E so that (sn f ) is
uniformly universal on E for some f ∈ C(T). Again, it would be interesting
to know for which sets E ∈ K(T) such functions exist. Due to Carleson's theorem, they necessarily have to have vanishing Lebesgue measure, and thus are
in particular nowhere dense in T. The proofs in Section 2 show that a "localized version" of Theorem 2 is true, i.e. for each compact set E0 ⊂ T quasi all
f ∈ C(T) are so that (sn f ) is uniformly universal on E for quasi all E ∈ K(E0 ).

2

 Since C(T) is dense in Lp (T) for all 1 ≤ p < ∞, and since sn : Lp (T) → C(T)
is continuous for all n, the proofs in Section 2 show that the Theorems 1 and
2 also hold with Lp (T) instead of C(T). In view of Kolmogorov's result on
the divergence everwhere of Fourier series of (quasi-all) L1 -functions (see [Kah],
Theorem 1.5), it is reasonable to suspect that in the L1 -case not only sets E of
vanishing Lebesgue measure are permitted. However, compact sets E such that
(sn f ) is uniformly universal on E for some integrable f still have to be nowhere
dense (see [Kah], p. 157).
